11:14 am
PM

hehehe

BE

But it's trying to turn around while trading in all the wrong places. Such as emerging markets and employing minimum wage security people.

Note, also Securicor's doing relatively okay.

11:15 am
BE

Which we wrote about here quite recently: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3r6KF4DAQ

BE

But Securicor's buying IOT CCTV companies and stuff like that.

BE

G4S is still very much an "employ a guy to sit in a shed and drink tea all night" company.

11:16 am
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Our view: Management is talking a LT improvement story. However,
exceptionals, business shrinkage and downgrades continue. Investment is
tough while net debt/ebitda remains so high. We see Cash Handling as a
structural drag, while there are uncertainties into 16E (e.g. EM). A poor
performer this year (-10% vs. FTSE100), but full valuation relative to peers.

BE

Forecasts - We cut 2016 EPS est. again by 6%. In Sept 2013 (post raising
under new management) our 2016 EBITA est.was £581m; it is now £443m.
While partly currency-related, this represents a downgrade of 24%.
2015E: We think most divisions are trading in line with our view - the
US is strong, UK and Europe tough. The EM operations are trading as in
1H, adjusting for the distortion of e.g. the Manus contract, although we
believe regions such as LatAm and Africa have been a bit softer of late. We
also reduce 15E sales by £100m (again moves to "discontinued"). This has
no effect on EBITA. However, we are again lowering the revenue base.
Bonuses are a swing factor (financial/personal - dependent on whether
goals are reached). We see this as a delta of perhaps £3-5m.
2016E: We lower 16E forecasts due to the UK and although we continue
to factor in strong EM growth, we have slightly tempered our view

11:16 am
BE

Contracts: The pipeline is seen as strong. Yet, there is little contract news
- a £40m/yr win in Iraq is the highlight although one should also note that
the £100m/year Bank of America contract is up for re-tender in 2H 2016.
Living Wage: G4S estimates 30% of its UK workforce is paid between the
Minimum and Living Wage. Some are under-25, so unaffected. The Living
Wage affects 2016 and G4S doesn't yet want to put a number on the
potential hit, while we assume those who are paid just above the Living
Wage will want a compensatory rise. This is not in our forecasts.
Cashflow: We see net debt flat vs. 2014. Net debt/ebitda remains at 2.7x
(3.3x pension adjusted; current pension review ongoing). The debt can
be re-financed to an extent from 2017E which ought to have a beneficial
effect as some of the rates are at 7% +. This is in our forecasts.
We had assumed the end of one-offs. We now expect to see more of
these in 2H 2015E - likely £15-20m of redundancy costs. There is no change
on contracts - we think cash costs on current onerous contracts will be ~
£20m/yr for the next 3 years). The dividend is barely covered by FCF in 16E.
Valuation: We value the stock on a DCF. We have extended this and
adjusted for the margin effects of revenues moving to discontinued, now
using terminal growth of 2% (no change) and a terminal margin of 6.6%.
We therefore lower our price target from 230p to 210p.

Miners bounced a bit this morning, but I'm struggling to see why

11:01 am
PM

Welcome

BE

Yeah. But this BHP update seems as reassuring as it can be under the circumstances.

BE

Shame not to have the rabble here on this subject. Some of our regulars are very animated right now about the potential cost of Samarco.

11:18 am
PM

http://www.investe...1511130700045977F/

BE

Clearly, there's only so much BHP can say so early into the tragedy.

BE

And into every information vacuum, a short seller will rush.

11:20 am
BE

Let me get Morningstar's summary of what's been said.

PM

At this stage, the tailings extend 440 kilometres downstream and 11 communities have been affected. Samarco has put in place a water monitoring program for the ongoing analysis of the water quality of the Gualaxo do Norte, Carmo and Doce Rivers. Samarco is working with relevant authorities to manage river water quality and ensure availability of potable water.

Samarco employees have been put on paid leave and options are being considered by Samarco for managing the workforce longer term.

BE

It feels callous to talk about BHP's dividend right now, but we sort-of have to.

11:21 am
PM

Go on then

BE

Basically, assuming $1bn "clean-up" costs, insurance cover for liabilities and Samarco out of action for three years or less, BHP doesn't really have to cut.

BE

Though there are considerable uncertainties in all three inputs there.

11:22 am
PM

Indeed

BE

We could start speculating about gross negligence claims, and suddenly we're back in BP territory.

BE

It may be that management feels a divi cut is contricious.

11:23 am
BE

Here's what Morningstar thinks.

BE

Failure of a tailings dam and damage to another at the 50%-
owned Samarco iron ore mine in Brazil, in joint venture with
Vale, is a disaster. The environmental mess and loss of life
dents investor confidence at a time when sentiment for BHP
Billiton is fragile as a result of falling commodity prices.
Managing director Andrew Mackenzie has responded
admirably in trying circumstances, promptly on the ground,
offering sincere condolences and pledging BHP's full
support in the recovery. That said, in no way do we put a
positive spin on the event for BHP.
Given the uncertainty around the remediation cost and any
possible restart, we have removed Samarco from our
earnings forecasts and fair value, but the direct impact is
quite small. Our fair value estimate falls 3% to AUD 29 per
share. Forecast fiscal 2016 earnings decline 9% to USD 0.35
per share and fiscal 2017 by 5% to USD 0.81 per share. We
still expect free cash flow to cover our unchanged USD 1.24
per share dividend forecast in fiscal 2016 and 2017, but it’s
skinny, averaging just USD 0.10 per share in those years.

BE

We maintain our narrow moat rating, reflective of BHP's
low-cost positions, notably in iron ore. However, lost
Samarco earnings means it will be several years before
group returns again exceed BHP's cost of capital. Our fair
value uncertainty rating worsens from medium to high.
BHP's medium uncertainty was an outlier in our global
mining coverage, but we're no longer satisfied the firm's
diversification is sufficient to justify a distinction versus
peers. BHP's key commodities, namely oil, coal, iron ore and
copper have been relatively correlated in the downturn. Our
high fair value uncertainty rating better reflects operating
leverage and cyclicality inherent in BHP and brings it into
line with peers. Also, lower earnings means the balance
sheet is now sound rather than strong, with some pressure
on the credit rating. We forecast EBIT interest cover to
trough at less than 3 times in fiscal 2016.
In terms of quantifying the impact of the Samarco disaster,
it's very difficult. It wouldn’t surprise to see remediation
costs reach USD 1 billion, but at this early stage, no one
really knows. Compensating the victims, cleaning up the
tailings and exposure to the loss of income from
downstream industry will be costly. There is a small chance
remediation costs could have a further impact on the fair
value estimates for BHP and Vale. The tailings dam will need
to be rebuilt if operations are to restart, but much needs to
be done to repair BHP's reputation before that can be
considered, regardless of economics.

11:24 am
BE

We had previously forecast Samarco to contribute
approximately 4% to group EBIT and valued the venture at
USD 2.4 billion. Group earnings for our five-year forecast
period decline by approximately USD 0.04 per share per
annum as a result of removing Samarco from our forecasts.
Costly investments made during the boom, such as iron ore
and U.S. onshore shale gas, weigh greatly on returns,
particularly given the subsequent commodity downturn. In
the five years ended fiscal 2012, BHP's return on invested
capital averaged 25%, but those heady days are gone,
reflecting the weaker external environment and balance
sheet obesity from boom-time spending. We only forecast
returns to reach 9% by fiscal 2020.

BE

And Citi.

BE

fjp73....

11:26 am
PM

Short coverage – predominantly the reason for the bounce.

For the wider market, the marginal producers are now at risks of needing to raise capital to reduce their debt burdens just to survive. The banks are unlikely without the shareholder support to continue this support as displayed by the likes of Standard Charter. Overall, what reason is there to hold the sector bar Rio and that’s if one must hold something.

We need not forget Chinese is now attempting to be a consumer and infrastructure projects have stalled, growth is limited and any stimulus is side-tracked until they can find a muppet to sign off to avoid the risks of being implicated in fraud. Liquidity attempts have done absolutely nothing to improve demand…We’ll not ignore the emerging markets either. Non-performing loans will be a key theme going forward…over to Standard Chartered.

We have examples of why not to be bullish – Examples being BHP Billiton.

PM

BHP Thoughts - 1) Tailings Damn
a. Fines.
b. Compensation.
c. Negligence.
d. Loss of revenue.
e. Loss of Profits.
2) Royalty Taxation in Australia – anther AUD$250M charged.
3) Lower Iron ore Price.
4) China’s switch to consumption.
5) Oil prices dropping further.
6) Fully-blown price taker.

BE

Well, that's a view.
